definitions.definition: To turn back , or turn to the contrary ; to reverse .
To throw back ; to reflect ; to reverberate . (Can we add an example for this sense?)
To cause to return to a former condition.
To reverse a change made by (a person).
To return to the possession of.
examples: When a book goes out of print, rights revert from the publisher to the author.

subdefinitions.definition: Of an estate : To return to its former owner , or to his or her heirs, when a grant comes to an end.

definitions.definition: To cause (a property or rights) to return to the previous owner.
examples: Sometimes a publisher will automatically revert rights back to an author once a book has gone out of print.

definitions.definition: To return to a former practice, condition, belief, etc.
To return to an earlier or primitive type or state; to take on the traits or characters of an ancestral type.
To change back, as from a soluble to an insoluble state or the reverse.
examples: Phosphoric acid in certain fertilizers reverts .

definitions.definition: To take up again or return to a previous topic.

examples: If they attack, we will revert to the bunker.

definitions.definition: To treat (a series , such as y = a + b x + c x 2 + ⋯ {\displaystyle y=a+bx+cx^{2}+\cdots } , where one variable y {\displaystyle y} is expressed in powers of a second variable x {\displaystyle x} ), so as to find the second variable x {\displaystyle x} expressed in a series arranged in powers of y {\displaystyle y} .

main_definition: ( transitive , now rare ) To turn back , or turn to the contrary ; to reverse .
secondary_definitions: To throw back ; to reflect ; to reverberate . (Can we add an example for this sense?)
( transitive ) To cause to return to a former condition.
( transitive ) To reverse a change made by (a person).
( intransitive ) To return to the possession of.
( transitive ) To cause (a property or rights) to return to the previous owner.
( intransitive ) To return to a former practice, condition, belief, etc.
( intransitive , biology ) To return to an earlier or primitive type or state; to take on the traits or characters of an ancestral type.
( intransitive ) To change back, as from a soluble to an insoluble state or the reverse.
( intransitive ) To take up again or return to a previous topic.
( intransitive , now rare ) To return; to come back .
( intransitive , Islam ) To convert to Islam.
( intransitive , originally India , now global ) To reply (to correspondence , etc.).

( transitive , mathematics ) To treat (a series , such as y = a + b x + c x 2 + ⋯ {\displaystyle y=a+bx+cx^{2}+\cdots } , where one variable y {\displaystyle y} is expressed in powers of a second variable x {\displaystyle x} ), so as to find the second variable x {\displaystyle x} expressed in a series arranged in powers of y {\displaystyle y} .
